items.title: 1.4.7 release
items.body: 1.4.6 worked fine with the latest pyparsing, the only problem was in the tests where exception messages had changed.

items.title: 1.4.6 release
items.body: 1.4.5 broke the tests for Python 2.7, which is still important for 6 more months.

items.title: test_real_operand fails on Debian unstable
items.body:
The python-snuggs Debian package failed to build after the update to 1.4.5:

```
   dh_auto_test -O--buildsystem=pybuild -O--parallel
I: pybuild base:217: cd /build/python-snuggs-1.4.5/.pybuild/cpython2_2.7_snuggs/build; python2.7 -m pytest /build/python-snuggs-1.4.5/test_snuggs.py
============================= test session starts ==============================
platform linux2 -- Python 2.7.16, pytest-3.10.1, py-1.7.0, pluggy-0.8.0
hypothesis profile 'default' -> database=DirectoryBasedExampleDatabase('/build/python-snuggs-1.4.5/.pybuild/cpython2_2.7_snuggs/build/.hypothesis/examples')
rootdir: /build/python-snuggs-1.4.5, inifile:
plugins: hypothesis-3.71.11
collected 37 items

../../../test_snuggs.py .F........x..........................            [100%]

=================================== FAILURES ===================================
______________________________ test_real_operand _______________________________

    @given(floats(allow_infinity=False, allow_nan=False))
>   def test_real_operand(num):

../../../test_snuggs.py:32: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 
/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/hypothesis/core.py:519: in execute
    result = self.test_runner(data, run)
/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/hypothesis/executors.py:58: in default_new_style_executor
    return function(data)
/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/hypothesis/core.py:517: in run
    return test(*args, **kwargs)
../../../test_snuggs.py:32: in test_real_operand
    def test_real_operand(num):
/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/hypothesis/core.py:464: in test
    result = self.test(*args, **kwargs)
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 

num = 1000000000001.0

    @given(floats(allow_infinity=False, allow_nan=False))
    def test_real_operand(num):
>       assert list(snuggs.operand.parseString(str(num))) == [num]
E       assert [1000000000000.0] == [1000000000001.0]
E         At index 0 diff: 1000000000000.0 != 1000000000001.0
E         Use -v to get the full diff

../../../test_snuggs.py:33: AssertionError
---------------------------------- Hypothesis ----------------------------------
Falsifying example: test_real_operand(num=1000000000001.0)
================ 1 failed, 35 passed, 1 xfailed in 0.83 seconds ================
E: pybuild pybuild:341: test: plugin distutils failed with: exit code=1: cd /build/python-snuggs-1.4.5/.pybuild/cpython2_2.7_snuggs/build; python2.7 -m pytest /build/python-snuggs-1.4.5/test_snuggs.py
```

items.title: Large floats fail to parse
items.body:
This is triggered by the new hypotheses test that hits a large value:

```pytb
______________________________ test_real_operand _______________________________

    @given(floats(allow_infinity=False, allow_nan=False))
>   def test_real_operand(num):

test_snuggs.py:32: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 
/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/hypothesis/core.py:604: in execute
    result = self.test_runner(data, run)
/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/hypothesis/executors.py:58: in default_new_style_executor
    return function(data)
/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/hypothesis/core.py:595: in run
    return test(*args, **kwargs)
test_snuggs.py:32: in test_real_operand
    def test_real_operand(num):
/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/hypothesis/core.py:542: in test
    result = self.test(*args, **kwargs)
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 

num = 1000000000001.0

    @given(floats(allow_infinity=False, allow_nan=False))
    def test_real_operand(num):
>       assert list(snuggs.operand.parseString(str(num))) == [num]
E       assert [1000000000000.0] == [1000000000001.0]
E         At index 0 diff: 1000000000000.0 != 1000000000001.0
E         Full diff:
E         - [1000000000000.0]
E         ?              ^
E         + [1000000000001.0]
E         ?              ^

test_snuggs.py:33: AssertionError
---------------------------------- Hypothesis ----------------------------------
Falsifying example: test_real_operand(num=1000000000001.0)
================ 1 failed, 35 passed, 1 xfailed in 1.47 seconds ================
```

items.title: 1.4.5 release
items.body: 1.4.4 introduced a bug: ints were parsed as floats #19.

items.title: Switch to use of "number" from pyparsing_common
Negative decimal numbers not parsed correctly
items.body:
Came here via rasterio calc. Apparently snuggs does not parse negative decimal numbers correctly. 

Below statement returns False:
```
snuggs.eval("(< -0.9 0)")
```
Comparing with a whole negative number returns True:
```
snuggs.eval("(< -1 0)")
```
Apparently the parser misses the sign when parsing a decimal number above -1. Compare:
```
snuggs.eval("(+ -0.9 0)")
snuggs.eval("(+ -1.7 0)")
```

items.title: Tests are broken with pyparsing 2.4.0
items.body: For now, I'm pinning pyparsing at 2.3.1 in the Travis builds, but we'll need to get the tests to pass with 2.4 sooner or later.

items.title: Why is click required?
items.body: A search on GitHub only seems to find it in `setup.py`; is it truly needed?

items.title: Missing "LICENSE" file in the source distribution
items.body:
I think the source distribution is a "substantial portion of the Software", so the license file should probably be included.

A MANIFEST.in file with the `include LICENSE` oneliner should be enough to do that, but perhaps it's not the only missing file that should be included in the source distribution.

items.title: Assumptions of particular keyword argument order don't hold for Python < 3.6
items.body:
Adding more keyword arguments to `test_snuggs.py:test_arr_lookup` demonstrates the problem

```
    def test_arr_lookup(ones):
        r = snuggs.eval('(read 1)', foo=ones, bar=2.0 * ones, a=3.0 * ones)
>       assert list(r.flatten()) == [1, 1, 1, 1]
E       assert [3.0, 3.0, 3.0, 3.0] == [1, 1, 1, 1]
E         At index 0 diff: 3.0 != 1
E         Use -v to get the full diff
```

This creates problems downstream for Rasterio's rio-calc: https://github.com/mapbox/rasterio/issues/947.

items.title: 1.4.0 release
items.body: We have a great new feature in #7. Totally warrants a new release.

items.title: Provide proper mask copying for numpy versions <= 1.8.2
items.body: As pointed out in https://github.com/mapbox/rasterio/issues/380, snuggs relies on the code in https://github.com/numpy/numpy/commit/ad902ff2e3b2be2bc33b65e6eaef857a2d3b5e6b and needs to provide this missing feature for numpy versions <= 1.8.2.

items.title: Use of numpy module ufuncs in op_map clobbers masked arrays
items.body: At the very least, we need to dispatch to ufuncs from `numpy.ma`.

items.title: Support for None/null/nil
items.body:
Specifically so we can evaluate

```
"(asarray (fillnodata (band 1 1) nil 20) (fillnodata (band 1 2) nil 20) (fillnodata (band 1 3) nil 20))"
```

with rio-calc, specifying a smaller max search distance.
